Subject: Re: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
From: Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...>

> I have grave concerns that once JUnit goes truly Open Source, it
> will cease to be a lightweight, simple test framework.

Erich and Kent have expressed the desire to keep an eye on the framework.  So I think they will keep the framework lightweight.

Over the last past months, only few requests concerned the framework ("count assert" and "compare arrays").  So I think that the framework is mature and that not many extensions will beadded in the future.

The count of assertions is simple and it is always possible to create a "manager only" version of JUnit.  As JUnit is a development tool and not a management tool I think it's wise to keep tasks separated.

-Vladimir
subject: Re: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
